Dermatitis.name: Dermatitis (Skin Inflammation)
Dermatitis.description: General inflammation of the skin that can be caused by allergies (food, environmental), irritants (chemicals, plants), infections, or parasites. Very common in dogs.
Dermatitis.treatment: Depends on underlying cause. May include antihistamines, steroids, antibiotics, or elimination diets. Identify and avoid triggers when possible.
Dermatitis.urgency: Low to Moderate - Monitor and see vet if worsening

Fungal_infections.name: Fungal Skin Infections
Fungal_infections.description: Fungal infections of the skin, most commonly ringworm (dermatophytosis) or yeast infections (Malassezia). Thrive in warm, moist environments.
Fungal_infections.treatment: Antifungal medications (topical or oral), medicated shampoos. Clean and disinfect environment. Ringworm is contagious to humans and other animals.
Fungal_infections.urgency: Moderate - See vet within 1 week, isolate from other pets

Healthy.name: Healthy Skin
Healthy.description: No signs of skin disease detected. The skin appears normal with no lesions, redness, hair loss, or other abnormalities.
Healthy.treatment: Continue regular grooming, balanced diet, and routine veterinary checkups. Monitor for any changes in skin condition.

Hypersensitivity.name: Hypersensitivity (Allergic Reaction)
Hypersensitivity.description: Allergic reaction causing skin inflammation. Can be triggered by fleas (flea allergy dermatitis), food allergens, or environmental allergens (pollen, dust mites, mold).
Hypersensitivity.treatment: Identify and remove allergen when possible. Treatments include antihistamines, steroids, immunotherapy, hypoallergenic diets, and flea prevention.
Hypersensitivity.urgency: Low to Moderate - See vet if persistent or severe

demodicosis.name: Demodicosis (Demodectic Mange)
demodicosis.description: Caused by Demodex mites that live in hair follicles. Can be localized (affecting small areas) or generalized (affecting large areas of the body). Common in puppies and dogs with weakened immune systems.
demodicosis.treatment: Requires veterinary diagnosis and treatment with antiparasitic medications (ivermectin, milbemycin, or moxidectin). Treatment may take several months.
symptoms: Hair loss (especially around eyes, mouth, and front legs)

ringworm.name: Ringworm (Dermatophytosis)
ringworm.description: Highly contagious fungal infection that affects the skin, hair, and nails. Despite the name, it's not caused by a worm but by dermatophyte fungi. Can spread to humans and other animals.
ringworm.treatment: Antifungal medications (griseofulvin, itraconazole), medicated shampoos, environmental decontamination. Isolate infected animals. Treatment typically lasts 6-12 weeks.
ringworm.urgency: Moderate - See vet within 1 week, quarantine immediately
